article:
The 'binding problem' is a term used at the interface between neuroscience,
cognitive science and philosophy of mind that suffers from having multiple
meanings. Revonsuo reviewed a spectrum of meanings and identified two common
versions, Revonsuo, A. (1999) Binding and the Phenomenal Unity of
Consciousness. Consciousness and Cognition 8, 173-185.  corresponding
broadly to what Smythies called BP1 and BP2 Smythies, J.R. (1994) The walls
of Platoâs cave. Aldershot, Avebury. Smythies, J.R. (1994) Requiem for
the identity theory. Inquiry, 37, 311-329. . Although there may be an
argument for separating these formally, there are reasons for thinking that they
are inter-related, even if in ways we do not understand. Moreover, the
historical literature is often ambiguous as to whether it is addressing BP1, BP2
or both [1,2,3].

Firstly, there is the practical computational problem of how brains segregate
elements in complex patterns of sensory input so that they are allocated to
discrete 'objects'. In other words, when we see a blue square and a yellow
circle, what neural mechanisms ensure that the sensing of blue is handled with
square and yellow is handled with circle (and not vice versa)?

Secondly, there is the problem of how objects, background and abstract or
emotional features are combined in phenomenal experience: "how the unity of
conscious perception is brought about by the distributed activities of the
central nervous system." Revonsuo, A. and Newman, J. (1999). Binding and
Consciousness. Consciousness and Cognition 8, 123-127.

The first question is a conventional one about the physical basis of computation
that could equally be applied to a mechanical computer. The second specifically
invokes a concept of subjective experience or phenomenality. As such it is
arguably outside the current scope of physical science in that although the
'unity' in 'unity of consciousness' is an intuitive feature of experience it is
unclear what it might mean in terms of physics. Perhaps the clearest exposition
of BP2 is in William James's Principles of Psychology James, W. Principles
of Psychology (1890) Chapter 6, free access online at
http://psychclassics.yorku.ca/James/Principles/index.htm where he refers
to it as the combination problem.
